title: Quiz 2: NCK Paper One - July 2011
description: Licensure Examination covering General Nursing and Medical-Surgical Nursing (July 2011).

questions.question: Nursing management of contusion of the eye includes:

options.text: Encouraging the client to lie supine quietly
Applying a warm compressor immediately after injury
Patching the eye closed until it can be examined
Flushing the eye with copious amounts of water

questions.explanation: Patching protects the eye from movement and light. Cold (not warm) compresses are used initially. Flushing is for chemical injuries.
questions.hint: The goal is to rest the eye and prevent further strain.

questions.question: The preferred position for a client following craniotomy is:

options.text: High Fowlers position
Turned to the operative side
Turned to the non-operative side
Low Fowlers position

questions.explanation: Positioning on the non-operative side prevents pressure on the surgical site. The head is usually elevated (Low Fowler's) to reduce ICP, but the side-lying instruction is specific to flap protection.
questions.hint: Avoid putting pressure directly on the surgical incision/bone flap.

questions.question: Laboratory findings that are consistent with hyperthyroidism include:

options.text: Decreased serum triiodothyronine (T3) and thyroxine (T4) levels
Elevated serum thyrotropin releasing hormone (TRH) levels
Decreased radioactive iodine uptake
Increased free triiodothyronine (T3) and thyroxine (T4) levels

questions.explanation: Hyperthyroidism involves overproduction of thyroid hormones (T3/T4). TSH is typically suppressed.
questions.hint: Hyper- means 'high' or 'excessive'.

questions.question: Blood supply to the gastrointestinal tract:

options.text: Originates from the aorta and branches to many arteries
Accounts for 10% of the cardiac output
Carries absorbed nutrients away from the lumen via the hepatic vein
Circulates through the liver by means of the portal vein

questions.explanation: The arterial supply comes from the abdominal aorta (Celiac, SMA, IMA). It accounts for ~25% of cardiac output.
questions.hint: Think about the major artery running down the abdomen.

questions.question: Breast tumours that respond best to adjuvant therapy are those that are:

options.text: Estrogen-receptor positive
Estrogen-receptor negative
Poorly differentiated
Locally infiltrating

questions.explanation: ER-positive tumors depend on estrogen for growth, making them susceptible to hormonal therapies (e.g., Tamoxifen) that block estrogen.
questions.hint: Hormonal therapy targets specific receptors on the cancer cells.

questions.question: A patient newly diagnosed with HIV/AIDS who laments, 'I can't believe I got this virus... How could I be so stupid?' is in the stage of:

options.text: Depression
Denial
Acceptance
Bargaining

questions.explanation: The phrase 'I can't believe I got this' is characteristic of Denial, the first stage of the Kubler-Ross grief cycle.
questions.hint: This is typically the immediate reaction to shocking news.

questions.question: Substances that create colloid osmotic pressure in the capillaries include:

options.text: Albumin, globulin
Plasma, potassium
Globulin, sodium
Albumin, potassium

questions.explanation: Colloid osmotic pressure (oncotic pressure) is exerted by large plasma proteins, primarily Albumin and Globulins, which cannot easily cross the capillary membrane.
questions.hint: Think about large proteins, not electrolytes.

questions.question: Discharge instructions for a client with chronic respiratory acidosis should include:

options.text: Discussing how to plan for periods of increased activity
Teaching about a low protein, low carbohydrate diet
Demonstrating exercises to increase vital capacity
Encouraging participation in activities such as jogging

questions.explanation: Respiratory acidosis results from hypoventilation/CO2 retention. Breathing exercises (like pursed-lip breathing) improve ventilation and vital capacity to help eliminate CO2.
questions.hint: The goal is to improve the efficiency of breathing.

questions.question: Inhalation anaesthetics are:

options.text: Muscle-relaxants used to facilitate surgery by paralyzing skeletal muscles
Non-opioid agent that produce anaesthesia or sedation
Opioid agents that produce unconsciousness during surgery
Organic liquids used for induction and or maintenance of general anaesthesia

questions.explanation: Volatile inhalation anesthetics are organic liquids (vaporized for use) that maintain general anesthesia.
questions.hint: These are liquids that are turned into gas/vapor for the patient to breathe.

questions.question: The predilection of HIV for certain cells in the immune system results in:

options.text: More T4 lymphocytes and general lymphocytopenia
Fewer activated B-cells and hypogammaglobulinemia
Increased response in cutaneous hypersensitivity
Susceptibility to opportunistic infection and neoplasm

questions.explanation: HIV destroys CD4+ T-cells, compromising cell-mediated immunity and making the host susceptible to opportunistic infections and cancers.
questions.hint: The virus weakens the immune system's defense against other diseases.

questions.question: A client with leukemia who develops tumor lysis syndrome would most likely have:

options.text: An elevated serum acid phosphate level
A decreased serum alkaline phosphate level
An increased serum uric acid level
A decreased serum calcium level

questions.explanation: Rapid cell breakdown releases DNA, which is metabolized to uric acid, causing hyperuricemia. (Decreased calcium is also seen, but Hyperuricemia is the direct metabolic by-product of DNA breakdown).
questions.hint: Cell breakdown releases DNA components which metabolize into this substance causing gout-like issues.

questions.question: Correct endotracheal (ET) placement is conclusively verified when:

options.text: Chest excursion is asymmetrical
Air emerges from the endotracheal tube
Breath sounds are bilaterally equal
Breath sounds are auscultated over the epigastrium

questions.explanation: Bilateral breath sounds confirm the tube is in the trachea and ventilating both lungs (not in the esophagus or right mainstem bronchus).
questions.hint: You want to hear air entering both sides of the chest.

questions.question: The most common preventable cause of valvular heart disease is:

options.text: Congenital disease acquired intrauterine
Calcium deposits and thrombus formation
Marfans syndrome
Beta-hemolytic streptococcal infection

questions.explanation: Untreated strep throat (Group A Beta-hemolytic streptococcus) causes Rheumatic Fever, which leads to Rheumatic Heart Disease (valve damage).
questions.hint: It starts with a sore throat.

questions.question: Initial treatment for a client with warm autoimmune hemolytic anaemia includes:

options.text: Intensive immunosuppressive therapy, radiotherapy
High dose corticosteroid therapy, administration of immunoglobulins
Transfusion with cryoprecipitate, chemotherapy
Radiation, transfusion with whole blood

questions.explanation: Corticosteroids are the first-line treatment to suppress the immune system's destruction of red blood cells.
questions.hint: The goal is to stop the immune system from attacking the body's own cells.

questions.question: Tympanometry is a:

options.text: Test to help determine inner ear problems such as otosclerosis
Subjective procedure to asses eardrum mobility
Procedure to diagnose serous otitis
Method used to assess Eustachian tube malfunction

questions.explanation: Tympanometry objectively measures tympanic membrane compliance and is diagnostic for fluid in the middle ear (serous otitis).
questions.hint: It tests the movement of the ear drum to find fluid.

questions.question: The respiratory problems that accompany peritonitis are as a result of:

options.text: Associated pain interfering with ventilation
Decreased pressure against the diaphragm
Increased oxygen demands from skeletal tissue
Fluid shifts to the thoracic cavity

questions.explanation: Severe abdominal pain causes the patient to take shallow breaths (splinting) to avoid moving the abdominal muscles/diaphragm.
questions.hint: When the abdomen hurts significantly, patients avoid taking deep breaths.

questions.question: An anorexic client states that her stomach is 'fat' and that all the food she is being forced to eat is making her obese. The nurse's best reply is:

options.text: 'Your body is starting to work normally again and is getting stronger and healthier'
'You have a bloated stomach because there is too much salt in your food'
'No, it's not, you look much better now than when you were first admitted'
'May be we have been feeding you too much and you're gaining weight too fast'

questions.explanation: This option offers a physiological explanation for the sensation (bloating) without validating the delusion of obesity or arguing with the patient directly. Note: In modern practice, therapeutic communication would focus on feelings, but based on NCK marking keys, this physiological explanation is often preferred.
questions.hint: Provide a factual, physiological reason for the sensation she is feeling.

questions.question: Skin changes in the elderly people leave them more susceptible to:

options.text: Heat stroke and heat exhaustion
Melasma and comedone formation
Hirsutism and heat retention
Seborrhea and scalp scaliness

questions.explanation: Loss of sweat glands and subcutaneous fat impairs thermoregulation, making the elderly prone to overheating.
questions.hint: The body loses its ability to cool down effectively.

questions.question: Match the objective client data with the musculo-skeletal disorder:
questions.explanation: Osteomalacia causes soft bones leading to deformities and waddling gait. Paget's disease involves high vascularity in bone, causing warmth over affected areas.
questions.hint: Soft bones cause walking issues; highly vascular bone remodeling causes heat.

questions.question: When teaching about proper use of antacids, the nurse should instruct the client to:

options.text: Stagger the administration of the antacids with other medications
Take the antacids with all other medications
Take other medications in the daytime and antacids at night
Drink a glass of water immediately after taking the antacids

questions.explanation: Antacids alter gastric pH and can bind to other drugs, preventing absorption. They should be taken 1-2 hours apart from other meds.
questions.hint: Antacids can interfere with how other drugs are absorbed.

questions.question: Why is Compartment Syndrome considered a medical emergency? (Select all that apply)

options.text: Increased pressure within a confined space
Compromised circulation to tissues
It causes immediate bone fractures
Leads to irreversible tissue necrosis
Causes nerve damage and loss of limb function

questions.explanation: Compartment syndrome involves pressure buildup that cuts off blood supply, leading to ischemia and permanent tissue/nerve death within hours.
questions.hint: Focus on the effects of pressure on blood flow and tissue survival.

questions.question: Select the appropriate nursing diagnoses for a client with urolithiasis (kidney stones):

options.text: Acute Pain related to inflammation/abrasion
Impaired Urinary Elimination related to obstruction
Risk for Infection related to urinary stasis
Decreased Cardiac Output
Deficient Knowledge related to prevention

questions.explanation: Diagnoses focus on the intense pain, blockage of urine flow, risk of infection from stasis, and the need for education to prevent recurrence.
questions.hint: Think about the symptoms: pain, blockage, potential for infection.

questions.question: Arrange the steps in the pathophysiology of Osteomyelitis in the correct order:

items.text: Inflammation and pus formation in medullary canal
Increased pressure within the rigid bone
Ischemia and necrosis of bone tissue
Formation of Sequestrum (dead bone) and Involucrum (new bone)

questions.explanation: Bacteria enter -> cause inflammation -> pus builds pressure -> blood supply is cut off (ischemia) -> bone dies (sequestrum).
questions.hint: Start with the bacteria entering and follow the consequences of the resulting pressure.
